thread.title: Tamil Nadu: DMK begins fast in Trichy in protest of ‘manhandling’ of MK Stalin in Assembly
thread.title_full: Tamil Nadu: DMK begins fast in Trichy in protest of ‘manhandling’ of MK Stalin in Assembly

author: FE Online
title: Tamil Nadu: DMK begins fast in Trichy in protest of ‘manhandling’ of MK Stalin in Assembly
text:
Tamil Nadu: DMK begins fast in Trichy in protest of ‘manhandling’ of MK Stalin in Assembly Tamil Nadu: DMK begins fast in Trichy in protest of ‘manhandling’ of MK Stalin in Assembly DMK led by its Working President MK Stalin on Wednesday began a hunger strike to protest what that party called was "murder of democracy" in Tamil Nadu. By: FE Online | New Delhi | Updated: February 22, 2017 9:42 AM DMK led by its Working President MK Stalin on Wednesday began a hunger strike to protest what that party called was “murder of democracy” in Tamil Nadu. (ANI image) 
DMK led by its Working President MK Stalin on Wednesday began a hunger strike to protest what that party called was “murder of democracy” in Tamil Nadu. The fast in Trichy is also to protest the alleged manhandling of the party Treasurer Stalin in the state Assembly on February 18 when the trust vote was taken up. Meanwhile, ruling Congress in Puducherry has extended support to the fast. In a release, Puducherry PWD Minister and PCC president A Namassivayam announced the party`s support to the DMK`s fast. DMK is an alliance partner of the Congress and supports the Narayanasamy-led government from outside. 
The opposition DMK had submitted a letter to Tamil Nadu Assembly Secretary AMP Jamaludeen for a No-Confidence Motion against Speaker P Dhanapal. The DMK’s move came a day after party Working President and Leader of Opposition in the Assembly MK Stalin said his party will move a No-Confidence Motion against the Speaker in the backdrop of the February 18 trust vote which Chief Minister E K Palaniswami won with a 122-11 margin. 
You may also like to watch 
“We have given a letter to the Assembly Secretary for bringing a No-Confidence Motion against Speaker Dhanapal,” Stalin told reporters at the Secretariat here. 
A copy of the letter has been submitted to the Speaker as well, he said. 
“During the session on February 18, the Speaker acted with ulterior motives. On that basis, given that there is no confidence on him, we have submitted the letter seeking a No-Confidence Motion against him,” he said. 
Watch this video 
Stalin had yesterday said DMK would move a No-Confidence Motion against Dhanapal, accusing him of “deliberately harping on his community to malign” the opposition party. 
His statement had come in response to Dhanapal’s charge on Saturday after the confidence vote faced by Palanisamy that he was perhaps targeted by the DMK during the ruckus for hailing from a particular community. 
“When we see that the Speaker is deliberately harping on his community to maligns us, it is very regrettable. It is a matter of shame, according to us, for Tamil Nadu,” Stalin had said. 
“Therefore, we will move a No-Confidence Motion (against Dhanapal). Signatures of 34 of our MLAs are enough for that and the (Assembly) rules mandate that it (motion) should be taken up within 15 days,” he had said. 
The DMK has 89 MLAs in the 234-member Tamil Nadu Assembly. 
On Saturday, amidst chaotic scenes involving the DMK which eventually led to eviction of its members enmasse, the Palaniswami government won the trust vote by the huge margin. Please Wait while comments are loading...
